15.61.text:
>> This is a commuter school

17.79.text:
you know, the stats show that
in, you know, the University

23.25.text:
There're a lot of people who
have jobs of other commitments.

26.45.text:
And from me as a student I'd
like to go to the office hours,

29.74.text:
I'd like to ask questions
and you might not have

31.67.text:
that opportunity in
lecture or office hours

33.97.text:
because they're once
a week at one time

36.54.text:
and you might have

40.96.text:
>> Straight from high school
it was my first time taking

44.59.text:
It's quite intimidating
being in the class of 500

47.07.text:
and not really confident
enough to go up

51.34.text:
I really wished I had some

54.33.text:
We didn't have any

56.91.text:
We didn't have any course

60.98.text:
And I found that I felt
really alone in the class

64.25.text:
and I think having experienced
the web enhanced lectures

67.64.text:
in my other courses, I know that
if I had them in my first year,

70.89.text:
I would even more
successful in that class.

82.90.text:
Those concerns of students
for accessibility, flexibility

88.19.text:
and engagement are what drive
this session on E-learning.

93.04.text:
My name is Avi Cohen, I
teach economics here at York

95.96.text:
and I'm one of the
participants in one

97.81.text:
of the academic innovation
fund projects.

101.00.text:
What we want to do in this
session is give you a taste

104.68.text:
of the variety of projects that
are going on around E-learning.

109.36.text: We can't go into great detail

111.20.text:
but if we do our job
well what we will hope is

114.75.text: that you will want to know more.

116.68.text:
There will be a question
and answer at the end

118.61.text:
of this session and then
all of us are going to be

120.92.text:
around for the day and to
come and pigeonhole us,

124.44.text:
pick our brains, ask us the
questions that you're thinking

127.66.text:
that you don't get to ask
during this presentation.

132.29.text:
All the projects are situated
along what Sue Vail is very fond

136.46.text:
of calling the E-learning
continuum which you see up here

141.32.text:
and let me take you through what
I think are the 4 most important

156.77.text:
This is the traditional
classroom setting.

159.69.text:
Those of you who have been in
the classroom for many years,

166.27.text: It's what we're all used to.

168.47.text:
Moving along the continuum
what web enhanced does is

172.12.text:
to maintain the traditional
face-to-face structure,

175.74.text: all of the course planning is

177.53.text:
as though it is a face-to-face
course but we add some resources

182.94.text:
on the web and this can range
anywhere from a course outline

186.96.text:
to recorded lectures and
everything in between.

191.12.text:
As we moved further along the
continuum to blended learning.

195.54.text:
This is where the
transformations start

199.77.text:
In blended learning, it's
still a combination of online

202.84.text:
and face-to-face but a couple of
things are crucially different.

206.95.text:
One, you reduce the
amount of face-to-face time

211.15.text:
which is obviously good
for commuter students.

214.37.text:
And two, what you
are forced to do is

220.86.text:
So you have to decide
as an instructor,

222.85.text:
all right if there are things
I want the students to know,

225.28.text:
I want them to be able to
do, I want them to feel,

228.72.text:
which of those learning
objectives are best achieved

233.04.text:
And which of those
learning objectives are best

236.81.text:
So there's a whole new
world of possibilities

239.52.text:
about where you situate
your activities

242.42.text:
and then how you integrate those
across the two different media.

247.14.text:
And then finally, there's
the fully online course.

251.46.text:
Obviously, everything
happens on the web.

255.10.text:
Now fully online courses can be
done very easily and very badly

260.30.text:
where basically you just
take your lecture notes

262.14.text:
from a traditional face-to-face
course and paste them

264.52.text: up on the web as PDFs

266.66.text:
or if they're done well they
also involve a fundamental

270.33.text: rethink of how you are going

271.91.text:
to achieve your learning
objectives given that you are

276.83.text:
the students will have different
needs and there's a lot

280.38.text:
to be done from an
instructor point of view

281.86.text: if you do fully online well.

284.65.text:
So we're going to be giving
you some examples of each

292.40.text:
Now, if all we were doing is
producing some web enhanced,

300.28.text:
we wouldn't be doing anything
new or innovative at all.

303.43.text:
Many instructors at many
universities had been doing this

306.54.text:
for years, almost
going on decades.

309.57.text:
What we're trying to
do that's different is

312.48.text:
to produce a scalable,
sustainable system

319.39.text:
whether there are web enhanced,
blended or fully online.

322.70.text:
And a system for producing
those courses requires 4

327.59.text:
One, there has to be
pedagogical support

331.23.text:
for the instructors 'cause most
instructors don't know what the

334.05.text:
challenges are in moving
to this variety of media.

341.90.text:
and design support 'cause
instructors are content experts.

345.43.text:
They're not technicians and
they shouldn't be expected

349.09.text:
Third, learner support
because the students

352.54.text:
in this environment face
different challenges

354.74.text: and they're going to need help.

356.58.text:
And fourth and finally,
assessment, we need to be able

360.58.text:
to benchmark what it is
that we're doing and we need

363.91.text:
to be able to figure out how
to feedback the information

366.88.text:
that we gather and to
improve what we're doing.

370.78.text:
Today, we're just going to be
telling you a lot of stories,

373.45.text:
a lot of anecdotes about
what people are doing.

376.82.text:
The plural of anecdotes
is not data.

381.02.text: In order to get real data,

383.23.text:
you have to use legitimate
research methodologies

386.48.text:
and we're engaging the services
of Ron Owston's Institute

390.94.text:
for Research on Learning
Technologies in all

393.35.text:
of these projects in order
to assess what we're doing

396.88.text:
and improve what
we're doing over time.

400.03.text:
So that's a sketch
of where we're going.

402.06.text:
So we're going to start
at the web enhanced

406.02.text:
and of the continuum and so I'd
like to bring on Merv Mosher.

412.23.text:
Merv Mosher has been teaching
at York for 30 years or more.

He's been an innovator
from the get-go

419.95.text:
and he teaches typically courses
involving the intimate number

426.37.text:
And he's going to tell you about
how he uses his web enhanced.

432.87.text:
I titled this presentation
from chalk to bits and bites.

437.87.text:
And what I intend to do is
explain how technology has

444.68.text:
enabled me to provide
educational experiences

449.07.text:
for large groups of students
that are richer, more engaging,

454.90.text:
and more accessible when
we have 700 students

458.73.text:
than when I first
started teaching

460.63.text:
and I have a course
of 70 students.

463.35.text:
Now that may seem like a fairly
bold claim to make but I'm going

466.98.text:
to focus on 3 areas to
try and emphasize this.

470.72.text:
The areas are quality,
accessibility and engagement.

474.86.text:
We can travel back real
quickly to the early 1980s,

480.20.text:
some of you may have
students at that time

482.73.text:
and we take the standard
lecture.

485.14.text:
It involved the professor, a
lectern, blackboard, and chalk.

491.98.text:
The resources available
to the student

494.26.text:
at the time were the
textbook and the professor.

498.24.text:
In other words, lectures
haven't changed very much

507.90.text:
Examine accessibility and
engagement at the time.

512.46.text:
My office was located
in Founders College

516.13.text:
because kinesiology didn't
have its own academic building

522.51.text:
Students seldom came for
office hours, those that did,

527.62.text:
indicated that the trek
over was rather onerous

532.21.text: and asked why I was isolated way

534.43.text:
over on the other
side of campus.

536.18.text:
After exams, I would post
the grades on my office door.

543.80.text:
Students complain bitterly
about having to hike that far

547.02.text:
and besieged me to
post the grades

549.41.text:
in the more central
location on campus.

551.92.text:
When I posted the solutions
to quizzes or exams,

558.64.text:
they invariably disappeared
off my office door

563.26.text: that far felt it was their right

565.77.text:
to take it rather
than copy down.

568.83.text:
So other students were
deprived to the answers.

571.98.text:
All of these problems
disappeared when I moved

577.51.text:
So let's fast forward
to the present.

583.12.text:
Kinesiology still doesn't
have an academic building.

586.86.text:
Our offices are spread
all over campus still

589.28.text:
and my class sizes
have gone from 70

593.08.text:
to as Avi have mentioned
500 to 750 students.

598.04.text:
But with technology and
what we at York here refer

603.12.text:
to as a web enhanced
model of course delivery,

606.49.text:
I'm able to provide
more engaging, richer,

613.22.text:
and better quality
experiences for the students.

617.20.text: Let's take some example of this.

619.78.text:
First off, I believe that one of
the great moments in teaching is

625.16.text:
when your students
have the "Aha" moment.

628.73.text: When they go, I get it.

630.05.text:
And I believe one of my roles is
to provide as many "Aha" moments

635.89.text:
as I possibly can
for my students.

639.59.text:
When I was first teaching
those "Aha' moments either came

645.85.text:
Now, we have access to a
global community of resources.

650.95.text:
I can go on YouTube
and find animations

655.23.text:
of almost every bodily function
and process that very well done

661.19.text:
and explains it far
better than I could.

663.95.text:
I can visit TEDTalks
or the Khan Academy

668.13.text:
and find wonderful explanations
of all sorts of concepts.

672.39.text:
If I want I can go to merlow.org
and find learning objects

677.68.text:
that had been posted by
instructors around the world

681.40.text: to be freely used in my courses.

684.47.text:
So quality has gone way
up because of the internet

699.04.text: I use Moodle a great deal.

701.59.text:
For those of you who
aren't aware as soon

704.66.text:
as a student enrolls
in a course,

707.56.text:
they are automatically
subscribed to a Moodle course

710.64.text:
or the Moodle website that is
affiliated with that course.

715.69.text:
Before the course starts, I
send students a welcoming e-mail

721.31.text:
and some explanations so already
I've started to make contact

724.56.text:
with the student prior
to the course starting.

726.24.text:
One of the things that
happens when you're involved

729.60.text:
in very large courses is what
I refer to as administrivia.

733.63.text: One example of this and it,

737.92.text:
it comes out in my welcome
message to the students.

743.14.text:
and they don't start taking
those courses 'til September

751.44.text:
they've got part time jobs that
are conflicting and it used

755.26.text:
to be that students would
come to me with their problem,

757.90.text:
students like to make their
problems your problems and I try

761.49.text:
and avoid that as
much as possible.

763.37.text:
And one of the ways is what
I refer to as lab swaps.

768.05.text:
So in my welcoming
message I indicate to them

771.08.text:
that I have a thread
posted here for those of you

773.77.text:
that have a problem
with your lab time.

776.19.text:
Post the time that you want
and the time that you have

779.89.text:
and you work out a swab, I
don't have to get involved.

783.72.text:
That freeze me up to do what
I love to do which is teach.

788.20.text:
All right, I don't have to
waste time to administrivia.

792.22.text:
Now, I believe that when you
have a group of 700 people,

796.86.text:
I actually have like 700
undergraduate assistants

801.68.text:
to do stuff for me and
I want to utilize them

805.77.text:
and so here is an
example of that.

808.03.text:
One of the things I do is I
give back my exams to students

814.45.text:
and if you know a student who
took the course last year,

818.16.text:
you have access to last
year's exam which is wonderful

821.37.text:
for that student but if you
don't know anybody who's

823.61.text:
in an upper year course, you
don't have access to it and so

827.21.text:
that students had a
disadvantage, so I eliminate

829.90.text:
that and I level the
playing field by posting all

833.30.text: of my last year's exams online

836.13.text:
but I don't give them the
answers despite their begging

841.12.text:
What I do is this, I say this
is quiz 1, you answer it.

848.22.text:
I'm sure the wisdom of the
crowd is going to come through

850.95.text:
and you will come
up with the answers.

853.26.text:
And so here is the
beginning of this thread.

855.33.text:
A student has said, "Here is
my answers, what do you think?"

859.69.text: And lots of stuff gets posted.

865.34.text:
I think you've done question 9
wrong, you need to fix this."

869.10.text:
This student has
gone on the internet

870.82.text:
and found a YouTube video that

874.67.text:

877.06.text:

Not only do the debate

"I don't understand, how

889.27.text:

892.17.text:
that comes back, "Phil,

893.95.text:
Oh, I couldn't have

896.40.text: I don't have to do any of this,

897.88.text:
the students do it

899.87.text:
So there's an example of

Now there're a couple

that are possible using

For example, in lecture, when

my lectures are generally

I have course kits
they can follow along,

Well that wasn't part

948.71.text:

so the students that weren't

957.37.text: as quickly as I was writing it,

959.58.text:
or weren't at class
now have access to it.

965.06.text:
And so changing on the fly is

970.69.text: I was going in this direction

but now I'm going

Another example of

976.72.text:

And so I was able to link that

994.91.text:
spur of the moment, put the post

999.35.text:
and students were
able to interact

1002.01.text: with it and follow-up on it.

Now one of the other

class and to listen to me talk

2744.83.text:
about stuff that I cared about,
into someone who, you know,

2748.62.text:
professor who believes
that maybe actually,

2751.06.text:
some of these interactive online
learning platforms might be the

2753.77.text:
best way to get people, to
care about these issues,

2756.82.text:
to active on these issues
and to discuss these issues.

2759.60.text:
And so now I'm, it involves in
transforming the York section

2762.88.text:
of the class into a blended
format where 50 perfect

2767.05.text:
of their activity will be online
and 50 percent of their activity

2770.88.text:
or in small tutorial sessions,
an extended tutorial sessions.

2774.63.text: And I'm hoping-- you know what,

2776.59.text:
I'm actually really
excited about this.

2777.74.text:
I'm hoping that it gets people
not only the flexibility

2780.32.text:
to do some of this work,
kind of it in their own time

2782.78.text:
and in geographic
location of their choosing,

2785.19.text:
but I actually think it's
going to increase the quality

2787.65.text:
and the ability of
them to interact both

2789.48.text: in tutorials as well as online.

2791.66.text:
And so, who knows,
maybe the year

2794.17.text:
or two we'll actually offer the
entire course online, we'll see.

2806.80.text:
A couples of things I love about
Robin's presentation, one is,

2811.49.text:
her excitement, and her
transformation, and two is,

2815.16.text:
the use of technology to
promote York's core values

2821.89.text:
So that gives you some
sense of the scope

2824.56.text:
of projects along the continuum,
we're going to bring everybody

2827.51.text:
up now for a Q and A. I'd
like to point out in closing

2834.15.text:
that even though
this was session

2836.03.text:
on E-Learning I hope
you've gotten the idea

2839.19.text:
that the technology
is not the point.

2842.23.text:
The technology is just a tool
and it's a tool that allows us

2847.08.text:
to address the needs
of York students most

2850.24.text:
of whom are commuter
students who work part-time

2853.18.text:
and it's addressing their
needs of accessibility

2856.13.text:
and of flexibility and of
engagement and of learning.

2861.55.text:
And we look forward to
sharing more of our results

2866.28.text:
So this is where we
open it up for question

2873.39.text:
I'm expecting that it'll take
you guys a few minutes to gather

2877.48.text:
up your courage to-- oh no it's
not taking a few minutes at all.

2884.79.text:
>> [Inaudible] a question
to Merv and Serban.

2889.45.text:
>> A question to Merv and
Serban, recognizing that this--

2892.63.text:
the continuum that
distinctions are artificial.

2896.68.text:
What is the difference
between what you Merv are doing

2900.69.text:
under the point of the
continuum of web enhanced

2904.22.text:
and what you are
doing as blended?

2906.93.text:
Do you see that each other
are doing something different

2910.20.text:
or are you just using different
labels for the same thing?

2914.97.text:
>> I would say that we are
doing something different.

2917.88.text:
I am continuing the lecture
face-to-face for the appropriate

2922.12.text:
or the normal amount and the
way I formulate the course is

2928.87.text:
entirely different then I
believe it would be done

2931.86.text:
if I were doing it
in a blended format.

2936.41.text:
>> Yes, the blended learning
format actually bringing the

2941.45.text:
both worlds, the only online
component to the classroom

2945.30.text:
and the classroom
to the online world.

2947.96.text:
So I'm teaching the course in
the lab-- in the computer lab.

2952.92.text:
to the online tools while
working collaboratively.

2957.00.text:
So this is the main difference
between all the courses.

2965.43.text:
>> Can I just add one
more point to that?

2967.17.text:
The definition of
blended requires that part

2969.50.text:
of the face-to-face time is
replaced by the online time.

2974.62.text:
So you don't attend the
class 3 hours a week,

2979.88.text:
You attend the class maybe
50 percent of the time

2982.50.text:
and the other 50 percent
time you're online working.

2989.70.text:
if you didn't recognized
her from the video.

2992.02.text:
Susan I wanted to
ask you a question

2994.19.text:
as well having been involved
with this for a long time,

2998.59.text:
was there anything
unexpected that happen

3006.17.text:
If I were to look back
and think about the things

3008.31.text:
or at least one thing that

3010.80.text:
that because our steering
committee was comprised

3014.88.text:
of representation from
two different faculties

3018.52.text:
and the university
information technology folks,

3026.85.text:
I mean we're talking a huge
number of people involved,

3029.70.text:
when all this respect
of academics

3032.22.text:
and everybody else went off to
their respective conferences,

3036.01.text:
they started talking about what
we we're doing here at York.

3038.91.text:
And all of a sudden we
started getting e-mails back

3041.71.text:
or the people start coming
back, they're saying "Oh,

3043.99.text:
[inaudible] is talking
about what we're doing here

3045.97.text:
or Miguel is talking about
what you're doing here.

3050.19.text:
It's now on York
and the perception

3053.01.text: of what we're doing is changing.

3055.94.text:
So I think that's really
important to understand

3058.47.text:
and to know that we have
this amazing opportunity

3061.25.text:
to do this right and this is
what we're attempting to do.

3069.23.text:
>> All right, thank you for
the interesting presentation.

3071.69.text:
I'm just wondering about
the shift from web enhanced

3074.02.text:
to blended learning in
the issue of resources.

3077.40.text:
Regarding do you
need more TA time

3080.61.text:
to deliver-- to make
that change.

3088.77.text:
>> In the shift, when
there are resources--

3091.84.text:
the resources that happen in
the number of different areas,

3094.25.text:
the first set of
resources are those devoted

3096.83.text:
to building the course
in terms of what it takes

3102.79.text:
And what we've done, thanks
to the funding both from AIF

3106.09.text:
as well as our respective
deans and our two faculties,

3110.23.text:
is to provide the training
and the technical support,

3115.52.text:
as well as, access to
funds for instructors

3122.12.text:
The transformation from web
enhanced to blended in terms

3126.12.text:
of TA time and probably
professor contact time depends a

3133.73.text:
Certainly any time you get
more student interaction

3141.27.text:
there's the chance
for more work.

3142.72.text:
I mean this happens in
a face-to-face course.

3144.57.text:
If you assign an extra
paper, you were going to have

3147.69.text:
to do more work because
you're looking personally

3150.54.text: at what the students have done.

3152.07.text:
In the online environment
there are ways to deal

3155.39.text:
with those kinds of numbers, for
example, many people have talked

3160.02.text:
about discussion boards and Merv
uses his in exactly this way

3164.55.text:
for his students answering
each other's questions.

3166.88.text:
One of the things I do in a
large course, 500 students

3170.25.text:
and I have 8 TAs, is the TAs are
assigned a segment of the course

3177.74.text:
who basically divide up the
students alphabetically and then

3180.55.text:
when students post a
question the first word

3183.54.text:
of the subject line has to be
the name of their TA and then

3186.30.text:
that TA is responsible for
answering that question.

3190.01.text:
One of the beauties of
that system compared

3192.63.text:
to a face-to-face situation or
face-to-face office hours is

3198.23.text:
when a question gets
answered one person benefits,

3202.89.text:
on a website the
entire class benefits.

3205.91.text:
So one of the things faculty
members learned in the training

3208.65.text:
that we do are all the ways
that you can leverage the tools

3212.25.text:
that are available
in order to try

3214.85.text:
and contain what the
work load issue would be.

3226.34.text:
We saw one minor drawback with
the technology in the classroom

3230.13.text:
and that was-- some, it
doesn't work sometimes.

3235.43.text:
and I think can be put aside,
but I would to like hear

3238.05.text:
from the group if you think
that there are any drawbacks

3241.25.text:
to technology and
the new environment

3244.72.text:
or is it really the
Golden Fleece.

3250.21.text:
>> I'll start with that, it's
not Golden Fleece of course,

3253.82.text:
there're always issues when
you're using a computer,

3256.38.text:
you know, something
is going to go wrong.

3257.99.text: But we have a great team.

3259.67.text:
We have the teaching
learning team.

3261.44.text:
Our IT people, they
were very responsive

3264.36.text:
and any time we needed
something they were there

3266.20.text:
to help us especially
with our group.

3268.47.text:
So certainly there
is learning pains

3270.45.text:
when you're starting
an online course,

3273.25.text:
but no more than if the
photocopier doesn't work

3276.44.text:
and you can't print
off your material.

3278.02.text:
So I think you can always
work through those things.

3281.07.text:
And as far as a blended
learning environment

3283.88.text:
or any online learning
environment with TAs and so

3287.44.text:
of standardized setting
for your website.

3290.96.text:
The people that are
helping you mark a grade

3294.09.text:
or helping you teach the course
actually have an easier time

3298.21.text:
in my opinion because
everything is laid out for them.

3302.62.text:
All the rules are
there and the teachers

3305.41.text:
and the students are
seeing the same information.

3307.81.text:
It's like a no surprise
environment.

3316.06.text:
The lecture capture that I
alluded to or demonstrated,

3319.61.text:
there is a drawback to
that, not the technology--

3322.83.text:
technology works
wonderfully, thanks to the folks

3325.84.text:
at the IT Department,
but those students

3331.31.text:
who aren't disciplined
enough to come to class

3334.20.text:
and watch the lecture
are in trouble.

3338.61.text:
And I would suggest that
probably the grade point average

3342.15.text:
in a large class
might actually drop

3344.36.text:
down somewhat using
lecture capturing that's

3347.88.text:
because the A students
can only go to an A plus.

3351.63.text:
The C student can go to a
D plus a D and E or an F.

3356.88.text:
So there's more room to
fall than there is to raise.

3359.71.text:
So I would say that--
you need to be careful

3364.08.text:
>> And I just want
to add to that--

3365.85.text:
I don't know if I'm
doubled Mark enough, but--

3369.34.text:
yeah that's why I
use lecture character

3371.17.text:
and then some instances with the
blended format which I'm moving

3373.65.text:
to now, of course they don't
have the option of coming

3376.55.text:
to class and listen to me
lecture all the time and half

3378.91.text:
of them are in person,
half of them are not.

3381.00.text:
So there is a discipline issue
like, I think it's a discipline

3383.69.text:
to actually sit down and watch
the lecture on time and not wait

3387.17.text: for last minute and so on.

3388.23.text:
I think that's one
of the drawbacks.

3390.27.text:
The others, that not
everyone learns that,

3392.60.text:
and I think this is
what Avi suggested is

3394.97.text:
that blended is actually
the most preferred,

3396.97.text:
you can get that kind of a
highest grade across board

3399.29.text:
because it gives a little bit of
everyone, you still get to talk

3401.72.text:
to the professor in person
every week if you need to

3404.54.text:
or if you want to, you can
spontaneously ask a question

3407.11.text:
to someone as they're, you know,
as they're watching and so on.

3409.35.text:
So there's-- I think some people
don't learn all that well online

3412.70.text:
and so they're probably not
going to be the kinds of people

3414.41.text:
who would take too
many online courses.

3415.93.text: So I think it's should be part

3417.29.text:
of us [inaudible] not
the only way to go.

3422.75.text:
A lot of this relies on really
good communications strategy

3426.32.text:
between the professor and the
student and so the examples

3429.16.text: as you've heard today-- I mean,

3430.28.text:
Merv begins every lecture
talking to students

3434.74.text:
and the benefits of the lecture
capture to informs them up front

3438.51.text:
and then he follows
up with then--

3440.49.text: I mean Serban had to e-mail some

3443.64.text:
of his student groups,
right, Serban?

3447.07.text: Do you want to speak to that?

3451.54.text:
So the beauty of the
blended learning modal is

3455.44.text:
that you can intervene early in
the course when you're seeing

3459.35.text:
that the students
are not participating

3463.75.text:
as I said all the student
work is continuously recorded

3468.99.text:
and you-- can keep track of
the progress of each student.

3472.69.text:
So students who are not
participating could be

3475.44.text:
approached and they, you
know and intervene early

3478.62.text:
in the course that
ran them at the end.

3482.46.text:
>> I want to throw in
one other disadvantage

3485.55.text:
from the instructor's
point of view.

3488.18.text:
All of this web enhanced,
but more especially blended

3491.51.text:
and online formats are
essentially a transformation

3494.72.text:
from a teacher centered model
to a learner centered model

3499.42.text:
and that's one of the reasons
why the reasons why the learning

3501.34.text:
outcomes get better is because
the learners get personally

3506.25.text:
But from an instructive point
of view, if you've been used

3509.07.text:
to being the king or queen
of the hill in the classroom

3512.28.text:
where you don't depend on other
people, you set the agenda

3516.01.text:
and the students
march to your drum,

3519.86.text:
this involves relinquishing
a whole lot of control

3522.99.text:
and I know certainly when I
did it the first time I hated

3527.46.text:
I'm very comfortable
knowing where things are

3530.47.text: and what's going to happen next.

3531.97.text:
And when you relinquish
that control you've got

3534.64.text:
to step back a little
bit and trust

3537.08.text:
that the students are going
to step in or nudge them

3540.09.text:
on the side to start
getting them

3542.48.text:
to do what you want you
them to do in the way

3544.54.text:
that other people have
suggested, but this is part

3546.50.text:
of what the resistance is
in moving to this models is

3550.21.text:
that you are moving
from a teacher centered

3559.22.text:
>> Just for the blended learning
and the online learning,

3565.20.text:
if the professors have virtual

3585.15.text: I myself haven't done the kind

of chat room thing

3589.56.text:
I imagine more who will attend

3596.52.text:
>> We have time for

3600.58.text:
>> You're pioneers

to thank you for

3606.14.text:
as at the positive virus
thought I'm not interested

3609.74.text:
I wanted to see how we can
infect my whole faculty

3613.02.text:
and how can we infect of all
York, so what's your insight

3617.88.text:
on how we can engage
more of your colleagues?

3621.78.text:
How do we take this really
compelling example and spread it

3625.33.text:
and get it to scale
and do it quickly?

3635.74.text:
Hi, Harvey, thanks
for the question.

3641.85.text:
we have to start small
because we want to do it right

3645.07.text:
and then you want a
reward what's done well.

3648.29.text:
So we had a recognition
event between LAMPS and how--

3651.48.text:
and at that event we joined up
with the experienced education,

3657.72.text:
And so between our two groups
and two faculties we had

3661.00.text:
about 45 people come out,
these are new people,

3663.44.text:
who are interested in adapting
their courses to either blended

3666.58.text:
or online or adding
the EE component to it.

3669.47.text: And so that's where it begins.

3670.72.text:
It's word of mouth, it's from
the grass roots level and,

3673.67.text:
you know, as each of us
go out into the world

3676.48.text:
and we start talking especially
these guys when they go out

3678.93.text:
and talk to their colleagues

3681.11.text:
and how it's working
and what works best,

3683.33.text:
it's about informing everybody
about best practices, right?

3686.59.text:
There's not one way
of doing any of this,

3688.64.text:
but there is certainly
things that work better

3690.30.text:
than other things and that's
what we're beginning to figure

3692.73.text:
out and we're passing on
to the best of our ability.

3696.49.text:
>> We are around all day,

Thank you for your

and we're looking forward to
